article.title: Gravity Modes Reveal the Internal Rotation of a Post-mass Transfer Gamma Doradus/Delta Scuti Hybrid Pulsator in Kepler Eclipsing Binary KIC 9592855

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure shows the observed composite spectrum of KIC 9592855 at orbital phase φ=0.18 (green line). The tomographically reconstructed individual spectra of the primary and secondary stars are indicated in black (shifted for clarity) with best-fitting model spectra overplotted in red. What does the overall appearance of the individual spectra suggest about the nature of these stars?
choices: They are likely red giants.
They are likely white dwarfs.
They are likely metallic line or Am stars.
They are likely very young, pre-main sequence stars.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure shows the Kepler light curve (black dots) and radial velocities (diamonds and crosses) of KIC 9592855.  The best-fitting binary model from the ELC code is overplotted in green (light curve) and black/red (radial velocities). What can be concluded from the light curve residuals (top panel)?
choices: The binary model fits the data perfectly, with no remaining residuals.
The residuals show strong, random variations suggesting significant stellar activity.
The residuals show a systematic trend, suggesting the presence of a third body.
The residuals show sinusoidal variations, suggesting an imperfect match of ellipsoidal variations.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure shows the time series and Fourier amplitude spectrum of the pulsation residuals of KIC 9592855 after subtracting the binary light curve. What do the pulsation frequencies highlighted by the red vertical lines in the bottom panel represent?
choices: They represent the orbital frequency of the binary.
They represent high-order pressure modes (p-modes).
They represent low-order gravity modes (g-modes).
They represent combination frequencies due to mode coupling.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure shows the evolution of theoretical pulsation frequencies and stability parameters (η) of a stellar model with a mass of 1.70 solar masses. The observed radius of the secondary star (R=1.96 ± 0.06 R⊙) is enclosed by the two vertical lines in each sub-panel of the upper part. What conclusion can be drawn from comparing the observed pulsation spectrum (overplotted in the bottom panel) and the theoretical instability parameters?
choices: The observed pulsations can be fully explained by the theoretical model.
The model can explain the high-frequency p-modes but not the low-frequency g-modes.
The model can explain the low-frequency g-modes but not the high-frequency p-modes.
The model cannot explain either the high-frequency p-modes or the low-frequency g-modes.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure shows the evolutionary tracks of stellar radius and the asymptotic period spacing of dipole (l=1) modes. The horizontal bars indicate the observed radii of the primary (green) and secondary (blue) stars. The gray shaded bar shows the observed period spacing of dipole modes. What is the main implication of the age discrepancy revealed by comparing the observed radii and period spacing with theoretical tracks?
choices: The system is coeval, and both stars formed at the same time.
The system has undergone mass transfer, with the primary accreting material from the secondary.
The secondary star is significantly older than the primary star.
The period spacing measurement is incorrect and must be re-analyzed.
